generated_section_content_md:
| This article **containspromotional content**. Please help improve it by
removing promotional language and inappropriate external links, and by adding
encyclopedic text written from a neutral point of view. _( February
2024)__(Learn how and when to remove this message)_  
---|---  
  
ESF headquarters in Strasbourg.

The **European Science Foundation** (**ESF**) is an association of 11 member
organizations devoted to scientific research in 8 European
countries.[_citation needed_] ESF is an independent, non-governmental, non-
profit organization that promotes science in Europe. It was established in
1974 and its offices are located in Strasbourg, France (headquarters).

ESF Member Organizations are research-performing and research-funding
organizations, academies and learned societies across Europe.

After four decades of stimulating European research through its networking,
ESF undertook a re-alignment and re-calibration of its strategic vision and
focus. The launch of its Expert division "Science Connect" beginning of 2017
marks the next phase of its evolution and has been born out of an
understanding of the science landscape, funding context and the needs of the
research community.
bullet_points: • This article contains promotional content and requests assistance in improving it by removing promotional language and inappropriate external links and by adding encyclopedic text written from a neutral point of view; notice dated February 2024 and includes the directive "Learn how and when to remove this message."
• ESF headquarters in Strasbourg.

• The European Science Foundation (ESF) is described as an association of 11 member organizations devoted to scientific research in 8 European countries [citation needed], and is characterized as an independent, non-governmental, non-profit organization that promotes science in Europe; it was established in 1974 and its offices are located in Strasbourg, France (headquarters).
• ESF Member Organizations comprise research-performing and research-funding organizations, academies and learned societies across Europe.

• After four decades of stimulating European research through its networking, ESF undertook a re-alignment and re-calibration of its strategic vision and focus, and the launch of its Expert division "Science Connect" at the beginning of 2017 marks the next phase of its evolution, described as born out of an understanding of the science landscape, funding context and the needs of the research community.

generated_section_content_md:
Up to 2015 ESF provided a platform for research scoping, planning and
networking on a European and global scale for ESF member organizations. ESF
activities were organized around three operational bases: strategy, synergy
and management. In line with its then mission and strategic plan, the European
Science Foundation ran programmes in science; programmes to enhance science
synergy such as research networking programmes and collaborative research
projects for European scientists; along with activities dedicated to science
management, such as providing administrative services to independent
scientific committees and other organizations.
bullet_points: • Up to 2015, the European Science Foundation (ESF) provided a platform for research scoping, planning and networking on a European and global scale specifically for ESF member organizations.
• ESF activities were organized around three operational bases—strategy, synergy and management—which structured its delivery of services and programmes.

• In line with its then mission and strategic plan, the European Science Foundation ran programmes in science and programmes to enhance science synergy, including explicit examples such as research networking programmes and collaborative research projects for European scientists.
• ESF also conducted activities dedicated to science management, notably providing administrative services to independent scientific committees and other organizations.

generated_section_content_md:
In June 2008, ESF in collaboration with EUROHORCs (European Heads of Research
Councils) published a policy briefing 'The EUROHORCs and ESF Vision on a
Globally Competitive ERA and their Road Map for Actions to Help Build it',
detailing essential requirements to build a globally competitive European
Research Area within the next five to ten years. At the time, EUROHORCs used
the European Science Foundation as an implementation agency. In 2014, this
instrument disappeared from the European landscape and has not been replaced
by any other funding mechanism.
bullet_points: • In June 2008, the European Science Foundation (ESF), in collaboration with EUROHORCs (European Heads of Research Councils), published a policy briefing entitled "The EUROHORCs and ESF Vision on a Globally Competitive ERA and their Road Map for Actions to Help Build it", setting out a coordinated vision and action plan.

• The 2008 policy briefing detailed the essential requirements to build a globally competitive European Research Area (ERA) within the next five to ten years, outlining strategic priorities and a road map for actions to achieve that objective.

• At the time of the 2008 publication, EUROHORCs used the European Science Foundation as an implementation agency, with ESF acting as the instrument to carry forward the proposed actions and measures.

• In 2014, this instrument—the European Science Foundation acting as the implementation/funding mechanism used by EUROHORCs—disappeared from the European landscape and has not been replaced by any other funding mechanism.

generated_section_content_md:
ESF has recently changed its scope of work. ESF has closed its traditional
research support activities (European Collaborative Research Projects,
Exploratory Workshops, Research Networking Programmes, etc.) and is focused
now on supporting the scientific community through scientific-support services
delivered by its Expert division (Science Connect).
bullet_points: • The European Science Foundation (ESF) has recently changed its scope of work and has closed its traditional research support activities, specifically including "European Collaborative Research Projects, Exploratory Workshops, Research Networking Programmes, etc."
• ESF is now focused on supporting the scientific community through scientific-support services delivered by its Expert division (Science Connect).

generated_section_content_md:
ESF is structured as follows:

* Governing bodies
* Science Connect Division
* Community of Experts
* Expert boards
bullet_points: • The European Science Foundation (ESF) is organized into four principal structural components, as presented: Governing bodies, Science Connect Division, Community of Experts, and Expert boards.
• Governing bodies: identified explicitly as one of the four core components of the European Science Foundation (ESF) structure.
• Science Connect Division: identified explicitly as one of the four core components of the European Science Foundation (ESF) structure.
• Community of Experts and Expert boards: each named explicitly as one of the four core components of the European Science Foundation (ESF) structure.

generated_section_content_md:
The annual _assembly_ is the highest level decision making body of the ESF. It
elects the ESF president, the Executive Board, ratifies the budget and
accounts and admits new members. The assembly delegates are appointed by ESF
member organizations.

The _Executive Board_ sets and direct the overall strategy of the ESF and
coordinates the relations with EU and other institutions. The Executive Board
consists of the ESF president and 3 to 8 member organizations. The Executive
Board meets twice a year.

The _President_ officially represents the ESF to the public and in relations
with other national or international organizations.

The _Chief Executive_ is responsible for the implementation of the strategy
and policy set by the Executive Board, for administration of the ESF office
and its finance and for ensuring the execution of the decision of the assembly
and the Governing Council.
bullet_points: • The annual assembly is the highest level decision making body of the ESF, elects the ESF president and the Executive Board, ratifies the budget and accounts, admits new members, and is composed of delegates who are appointed by ESF member organizations.

• The Executive Board, which is elected by the assembly, sets and directs the overall strategy of the ESF and coordinates the relations with the EU and other institutions; it consists of the ESF president and 3 to 8 member organizations and meets twice a year.
• The President, elected by the assembly, officially represents the ESF to the public and in relations with other national or international organizations.

• The Chief Executive is responsible for the implementation of the strategy and policy set by the Executive Board, for administration of the ESF office and its finance, and for ensuring the execution of the decision of the assembly and the Governing Council.

generated_section_content_md:
Science Connect is ESF's Expert services division dedicated to support
scientific decision-making through a range of science-support services, such
as Grant Evaluation, Career Tracking, coordination of EU-funded Projects and
the hosting of scientific platforms and Expert Boards.
bullet_points: • Science Connect is the European Science Foundation (ESF)’s Expert services division, explicitly designated to support scientific decision-making.
• The division is dedicated to providing a range of science-support services aimed at informing and enabling scientific decision-making processes.
• Specific services provided by Science Connect include Grant Evaluation, Career Tracking, coordination of EU-funded Projects, and the hosting of scientific platforms and Expert Boards.

generated_section_content_md:
According to the ESF website, the Community of Experts is a network of
international recognized experts that covers the full spectrum of the
scientific landscape (Humanities, Economics and Social Sciences, Physics,
Chemistry, Mathematics and Engineering Sciences, Earth and Environmental
Sciences, Life and Biomedical Sciences). Its role is to sustain scientific
collaboration and support excellence in research grant peer-review and
proposal evaluation across all scientific disciplines.

ESF's Community of Experts comprises two colleges:

* The College of Review Panel Members. Review Panel Members have a broad expertise in several scientific disciplines and their mission is to build consensus during the evaluation of research proposals.
* The College of Expert Reviewers. Expert Reviewers are scientists specialized in a specific scientific domain and are in charge of assessing and evaluating several types of proposals such as fellowship applications and research projects.
bullet_points: • According to the European Science Foundation (ESF) website, the Community of Experts is a network of internationally recognized experts that "covers the full spectrum of the scientific landscape" including the following domains: Humanities, Economics and Social Sciences, Physics, Chemistry, Mathematics and Engineering Sciences, Earth and Environmental Sciences, Life and Biomedical Sciences.

• The stated role of the ESF Community of Experts is to sustain scientific collaboration and to support excellence in research grant peer‑review and proposal evaluation across all scientific disciplines.

• ESF's Community of Experts comprises two colleges; the first, the College of Review Panel Members, consists of individuals with broad expertise across several scientific disciplines whose mission is to build consensus during the evaluation of research proposals.

• The second college, the College of Expert Reviewers, comprises scientists specialized in a specific scientific domain who are responsible for assessing and evaluating several types of proposals, explicitly including fellowship applications and research projects.

generated_section_content_md:
Since 1974 ESF has set up and hosted expert boards and committees in several
scientific domains. These include space sciences; radio-astronomy frequencies;
nuclear physics; marine and polar sciences; and materials science. At present
ESF hosts the following Expert Boards:
bullet_points: • Since 1974, the European Science Foundation (ESF) has set up and hosted expert boards and committees across multiple scientific domains, the exact founding year being 1974.

• The specific domains identified are space sciences; radio-astronomy frequencies; nuclear physics; marine and polar sciences; and materials science, and the source notes that "At present ESF hosts the following Expert Boards:" (the subsequent list of boards was not provided in the supplied content).

generated_section_content_md:
Established in 1974, the ESSC provides unbiased, expert advice to the space
scientific community including the European Space Agency, the European
Commission, EU national space agencies. Over the years, the ESSC has become
the reference body in Europe for independent scientific advice on space
matters and a key partner for international research collaboration.
bullet_points: • The European Space Sciences Committee (ESSC) was established in 1974 and is an expert advisory body in the field of space science.
• The ESSC provides unbiased, expert advice to the space scientific community, explicitly including the European Space Agency, the European Commission, and EU national space agencies.

• Over the years the ESSC has become the reference body in Europe for independent scientific advice on space matters and has established itself as a key partner for international research collaboration.

generated_section_content_md:
NuPECC's aim is to strengthen European collaboration in nuclear physics
through the definition of a network of complementary facilities within Europe.
NuPECC issues recommendations on the development, organization and support of
European nuclear physics and particular projects.
bullet_points: • In the chapter "European Science Foundation," the section "Nuclear Physics European Collaboration Committee (NuPECC)" identifies NuPECC (Nuclear Physics European Collaboration Committee) as focused on strengthening European collaboration in nuclear physics through the definition of a network of complementary facilities within Europe.

• NuPECC issues recommendations on the development, organization and support of European nuclear physics and on particular projects, thereby guiding the planning, coordination and backing of nuclear physics activities across Europe.

generated_section_content_md:
Established in 1988, CRAF represents all the major radio astronomical
observatories in Europe. CRAF initiates and encourages scientific studies
aimed at reducing radio astronomy interference at source and the effects of
interference. Throughout the years CRAF has become an active voice in Europe
and engages with other groups of radio astronomers in discussions with
international organizations that decide on the use of radio spectrum.
bullet_points: • Committee on Radio Astronomy Frequencies (CRAF), established in 1988 under the European Science Foundation, represents all the major radio astronomical observatories in Europe and serves as their collective voice on spectrum matters.

• CRAF’s core remit is to initiate and encourage scientific studies aimed at reducing radio astronomy interference at source and the effects of interference, promoting both mitigation at origin and research into impact reduction.
• Throughout the years CRAF has become an active voice in Europe, advocating for radio astronomy interests and raising awareness of interference issues among European stakeholders.

• CRAF actively engages with other groups of radio astronomers and participates in discussions with international organizations that decide on the use of radio spectrum, seeking to influence policy and regulatory decisions affecting radio astronomy.

• CRAF’s activities center on protecting radio astronomy access to the radio spectrum in Europe and internationally by coordinating observatory positions, fostering scientific studies, and representing European radio astronomy in spectrum allocation dialogues.

generated_section_content_md:
European Science Foundation Map

**Belgium**

* Fonds de la Recherche Scientifique – FNRS (F.R.S.–FNRS) (Fund for Scientific Research – FNRS (F.R.S.–FNRS))

**Bulgaria**

* Българска академия на науките (BAS) (Bulgarian Academy of Sciences)
* Научни изследвания (National Science Fund of Bulgaria)

**France**

* Institut Français de Recherche pour l'Exploitation de la Mer (IFREMER)(French Research Institute for Exploitation of the Sea)
* EuroScience (EuroScience)
* Core Technologies for Life Sciences (CTLS)

**Hungary**

* Magyar Tudományos Akadémia (MTA) (Hungarian Academy of Sciences)

**Luxembourg**

* Fonds National de la Recherche (FNR)

**Romania**

* Consiliul Național al Cercetării Științifice (National Council for Scientific Research -CNCS)

**Serbia**

* Српска академија наука и уметности (САНУ) (Serbian Academy of Sciences and Arts)

**Turkey**

* Türkiye Bilimsel ve Teknolojik Araştırma Kurumu (TÜBITAK) (Scientific and Technological Research Council of Turkey)
bullet_points: • European Science Foundation Map: list of member organizations by country as presented in the source material.
• Belgium — Fonds de la Recherche Scientifique – FNRS (F.R.S.–FNRS) (Fund for Scientific Research – FNRS (F.R.S.–FNRS)).
• Bulgaria — Българска академия на науките (BAS) (Bulgarian Academy of Sciences); Научни изследвания (National Science Fund of Bulgaria).

• France — Institut Français de Recherche pour l'Exploitation de la Mer (IFREMER)(French Research Institute for Exploitation of the Sea); EuroScience (EuroScience); Core Technologies for Life Sciences (CTLS).
• Hungary — Magyar Tudományos Akadémia (MTA) (Hungarian Academy of Sciences).
• Luxembourg — Fonds National de la Recherche (FNR).
• Romania — Consiliul Național al Cercetării Științifice (National Council for Scientific Research -CNCS).
• Serbia — Српска академија наука и уметности (САНУ) (Serbian Academy of Sciences and Arts).
• Turkey — Türkiye Bilimsel ve Teknolojik Araştırma Kurumu (TÜBITAK) (Scientific and Technological Research Council of Turkey).

generated_section_content_md:
* 1974–1979 Brian Flowers
* 1980–1984 Hubert Curien
* 1985–1990 Eugen Seibold
* 1991–1993 Umberto Colombo
* 1994–1999 Sir Dai Rees
* 2000–2005 Reinders van Duinen
* 2006–2011 Ian Halliday
* 2012–2015 Pär Omling
* 2016 – April 2020: Martin Hynes
* April 2020 to date: Véronique Halloin
bullet_points: • 1974–1979: Brian Flowers served as President of the European Science Foundation.
• 1980–1984: Hubert Curien served as President of the European Science Foundation.
• 1985–1990: Eugen Seibold served as President of the European Science Foundation.
• 1991–1993: Umberto Colombo served as President of the European Science Foundation.
• 1994–1999: Sir Dai Rees served as President of the European Science Foundation.
• 2000–2005: Reinders van Duinen served as President of the European Science Foundation.
• 2006–2011: Ian Halliday served as President of the European Science Foundation.
• 2012–2015: Pär Omling served as President of the European Science Foundation.
• 2016 – April 2020: Martin Hynes served as President of the European Science Foundation.
• April 2020 to date: Véronique Halloin serves as President of the European Science Foundation.

generated_section_content_md:
* 1974–1979 Friedrich Schneider
* 1980–1986 John Goormaghtigh
* 1986–1993 Michael Posner
* 1991–1993 Umberto Colombo
* 1993–1998 Peter Fricker
* 1998–2003 Enric Banda
* 2004–2007 Bertil Anderson
* 2007 John Marks
* 2008–2011 Marja Makarow
* 2012–2015 Martin Hynes
* 2016 – June 2019: Jean-Claude Worms
* July 2019 to date: Nicolas Walter
bullet_points: • European Science Foundation — chronological listing of Secretaries General and Chief Executives from 1974 to the present, providing officeholder names and exact tenures for institutional reference.
• 1974–1979 — Friedrich Schneider: served as Secretary General and Chief Executive of the European Science Foundation from 1974 to 1979.
• 1980–1986 — John Goormaghtigh: served as Secretary General and Chief Executive of the European Science Foundation from 1980 to 1986.

• 1986–1993 — Michael Posner: served as Secretary General and Chief Executive of the European Science Foundation from 1986 to 1993; tenure overlaps with Umberto Colombo for the period 1991–1993 as indicated in the record.

• 1991–1993 — Umberto Colombo: served as Secretary General and Chief Executive of the European Science Foundation from 1991 to 1993; this service coincides with part of Michael Posner’s 1986–1993 tenure.
• 1993–1998 — Peter Fricker: served as Secretary General and Chief Executive of the European Science Foundation from 1993 to 1998.
• 1998–2003 — Enric Banda: served as Secretary General and Chief Executive of the European Science Foundation from 1998 to 2003.
• 2004–2007 — Bertil Anderson: served as Secretary General and Chief Executive of the European Science Foundation from 2004 to 2007.
• 2007 — John Marks: served as Secretary General and Chief Executive of the European Science Foundation during the year 2007.
• 2008–2011 — Marja Makarow: served as Secretary General and Chief Executive of the European Science Foundation from 2008 to 2011.
• 2012–2015 — Martin Hynes: served as Secretary General and Chief Executive of the European Science Foundation from 2012 to 2015.
• 2016 – June 2019 — Jean-Claude Worms: served as Secretary General and Chief Executive of the European Science Foundation from 2016 until June 2019.
• July 2019 to date — Nicolas Walter: has served as Secretary General and Chief Executive of the European Science Foundation from July 2019 to date.
